utterances: Hi.
We'd also like to hear from you.
If you have a favorite moment where Peter Jennings touched you, aggravated you or helped you understand the world, give us a call: (800) 989-8255; (800) 989-TALK.
And the e-mail address is totn@npr.org.
And Robert Krulwich is with us from ABC News headquarters.
And we knew Peter Jennings from watching him on the television as a cool, collected anchor, a man who could truly think on his feet, and also understood more mundane stories.
What was he like as a person?
How did you know him?
He was pretty unusual--in a way it's very hard to describe.
But he was just big.
His appetites were big.
His talents were big.
His insecurities were big.
His sense of his ambition was big.
So when you hung around a guy like that, you could almost get exhausted standing next to him because he had so much--I don't--he was like an energy ball.
He would think faster, kind of--he would think past you.
He would whack you in the back if he thought that you were being weak.
You know, not fleet-footed enough.

And so there was a sense about this guy that he was--the closest I can get to it is if you happened to wander into the Iliad and actually met one of those Greek kings who just swaggered through life, Peter had a swagger, and I don't think I ever ran into anybody quite like him in that way.
In that way.
It takes, I think, a certain amount of swagger to take on the job that he did.
Well, it's a very strange job because you are both an actor, an improvisor, a wise man.
You're also a brand--I mean, think about that.
You have an entire company that pretty much treats your face as its face.
You have thousands of people working for you, any one of which could hand you a bad fact, a misstatement or whatever.
So you have to be on your guard--you have to be a lance, you have to be all these things, and he did it with an athlete's grace.
I mean, it was just fascinating to watch closely, 'cause you'd walk into a room.
He'd sit down in that chair and the world would throw all these different things at him.
The period of time around the World Trade Center was perhaps the most memorable example.
The story was sudden, the developments were very clear and very sudden as well.
But he seemed to get more and more relaxed.
Here's an e-mail we got from Theresa Bouwa(ph) in Wolcott, Indiana.
`My favorite Peter Jennings broadcast moment was his response to an enormous rusting ship that ran aground on the private beach of a very wealthy woman.
After the clip ran, Jennings tried to keep a straight face, but just couldn't.
His comment?
It's not really funny, but it is.""'
`We wait for Los Reyes Magos,' she says.

`Because Los Reyes Magos belong to us.
In Spain, we've only had Papa Noel lately.
When we were young, there was no Papa Noel.
Rodriguez notices that her daughter is listening to the grown-ups' conversation.

`Tonight the three wise men will come,' her mother says with the wink of an eye.
`They go to all the homes and bring presents.
We parents have nothing to do with it.
Rodriguez says her children will go to bed early because when they wake up, their presents, brought by the three wise men, will be waiting under the Christmas tree.
A boy with thick glasses joins the conversation.
Nine-year-old Jesus Garcia Castello(ph) is no dummy.
He knows how it works.
(Foreign language spoken)
`Los Reyes bring gifts to children who've been good,' he says.
`Those who've been naughty get chunks of coal.
He admits that he once got a small burlap bag with black-colored rock candy as a joke from his aunts.
But Jesus knows what this holiday is really about and he wants to remind everybody.
(Foreign language spoken)
`I want or I would like there to be no more war in some countries,' he says.
Then he holds out his hand, which has four small pieces of candy that he managed to pick up.
(Foreign language spoken)
And he says, `If you want, you can take some for the children in your country.
For NPR News, I'm Jerome Socolovsky in Madrid.
This is NPR News.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Robert Siegel.
And I'm Melissa Block.
In Los Angeles, police and the FBI have been learning a hard lesson, that street gangs are far more sophisticated than they thought.
In the final story of our series on the gangs of L.A., NPR's Mandalit del Barco explains how gang leaders have managed to call the shots even when they're in jail.
For more than a decade, the FBI has been trying to take down the 18th Street gang, but generations of gang leaders have made it difficult.
18th Street has as many as 30,000 members spread across Los Angeles and even into Central America.
But it's actually a collection of small groups or cliques like the notorious Columbia Lil Cycos.
They're known for murders, robberies, kidnappings; they make a lot of money selling dope.
LAPD gang officer Magdaleno Gomez sits in the windowless, rampart detective bureau he shares with FBI agents.
He says the Columbia Lil Cycos have ruled the streets of L.A.'s Westlake District since the 1960s.
Gomez says the clique offers protection from rival gangs in exchange for taxes or rent, essentially a cut of the profits from illegal street sales.

Whether it be narcotics, fake green cards or fake passports, fake driver licenses, they tax the illegal vendors - the people that sell food, anything counterfeit, anything illegal that goes on in the street, they take a cut from that.
Gomez's partner, Edgar Hernandez, says dealers and vendors understand the consequences of refusing to pay taxes to the clique.
Individuals that they don't want to pay for selling illegally on the streets have got shot, stabbed, and have even been murdered.
When one vendor stood up to the gang in September, he was shot, and a 23-day-old baby was killed.
Here's how TV news station KCAL reported it.
(SOUNDBITE OF TELEVISION NEWS)
Three gang members, apparently targeting 38-year-old Francisco Clemente, who was selling DVDs in the neighborhood, shot and critically wounded Clemente, but a stray bullet hit Baby Louise.
Six members of the Columbia Lil Cycos will soon stand trial for the baby's murder.
A month after the killing, the FBI arrested the leader of that clique - the so-called shot caller.
He was busted on federal charges for distributing crack cocaine along with his wife and 17 alleged associates and drug dealers.
His name is Sergio Pantoja, but he's known on the streets as Tricky.
Officer Hernandez says Tricky operated a tattoo parlor that was actually a front for an elaborate drug dealing and extortion racket.

Now, this tattoo shop, he had the emblem of the Mexican flag, the eagle eating the snake, kind of like some (unintelligible) and I would always tell him, why do you have that, you're from El Salvador?

Hernandez says Tricky's tattooed back, chest and arms are also filled with Aztec and Mexican symbols, possibly to show allegiance to the Mexican mafia, a huge Latino prison gang made up of leaders from many street gangs.
Tricky is just the latest alleged shot caller in a tangled hierarchy running from the streets to the prisons.
Who is ultimately at the top of that chain?
Puppet, he is the brother, he is the man, he (unintelligible)
He's not really the puppet.
He's the puppet master.
Pulling all the strings from federal prison.
Francisco ""Puppet"" Martinez is allegedly a member of the Mexican mafia, a target of an FBI takedown in 2003.
Bruce Riordan handled the case as a federal prosecutor.
Puppet Martinez was incarcerated at that time in federal prison on immigration charges.

However, the evidence showed that Mr. Martinez was still running the Columbia Lil Cycos from prison, and he was doing so through the auspices of his wife, Janey Garcia(ph), who was also known as La Senora, the lady boss of the gang, and an individual by the name of Juan Romero, who was also known as Termite.
Does the house have termites?
Yeah.

Got it.
Does the house have termites?
Yeah.
